entry.title: Re: S/4 HANA integration with SAP CRM
entry.content:
Yes, SAP S/4HANA has middleware capabilities similar to SAP ECC, but there are key differences. While SAP ECC uses SAP PI/PO (Process Integration/Process Orchestration) or SAP PI as the middleware for integration with external systems, SAP S/4HANA typically uses SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI) or SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) for cloud-based integration. These new tools are better suited for cloud-based applications and provide more advanced integration capabilities.

However, if you want to integrate SAP CRM with S/4HANA, you will need to use middleware such as SAP CPI or SAP BTP, which can enable seamless integration between S/4HANA and SAP CRM. It's important to note that with S/4HANA, SAP is moving towards cloud-based integration tools, and the traditional SAP PI/PO is being phased out in favor of these more modern platforms.

In summary, while the middleware concept remains similar, S/4HANA is more aligned with cloud-based integration tools like SAP CPI and SAP BTP compared to the older ECC system.

entry.title: Re: Understanding Non Valuated Stock and Text Items in SA...
entry.content:
Hi @AAkash1,

Non‚Äëvaluated stock in SAP MM/EWM means materials are physically tracked but carry no financial value in the system. This is useful for items like free‚Äëof‚Äëcharge samples, customer‚Äëowned stock, or certain packaging materials. EWM still requires product master data to represent them, but no accounting postings are triggered. Text items in EWM are purely informational‚Äîthey don‚Äôt create deliveries or warehouse tasks, with no exceptions for execution processes.

The No-valued material in practice because, the materials are tracked with both quantity and value; every goods movement posts to accounting. Even Non‚Äëvaluated stock materials are tracked only in terms of quantity; no financial postings occur. Business implication for the company knows what is physically in the warehouse but does not assign a book value to it.

Business Processes Where Non‚ÄëValuated Stock Makes Sense as Customer‚Äëowned stock, Materials sent by customers for repair or processing. The company tracks them but doesn‚Äôt own them financially.
Free‚Äëof‚Äëcharge samples or promotional items stock is managed for logistics but not valued in accounting. Consignment or project stock sometimes tracked non‚Äëvaluated to simplify accounting integration with external parties. Packaging materials not always non‚Äëvaluated. If packaging is a cost element (e.g., branded boxes), it can be valuated. If packaging is reusable or customer‚Äëprovided, it‚Äôs often non‚Äëvaluated. Decision depends on whether the company wants packaging costs reflected in financial statements.

Now the question is who pays and how consumption Is Handled. So the thing is customer‚Äëowned stock will be bear by customer the cost, company only provides service. I its a free samples, cost absorbed by the company at procurement stage itself. Consumption doesn‚Äôt trigger valuation postings.
In case of packaging is valuated, consumption posts to expense accounts; if non‚Äëvaluated, only quantity updates occur.

SAP MM vs. EWM Handling

SAP MM: Material types like UNBW (non‚Äëvaluated) or NLAG (non‚Äëstock) define valuation behavior. No FI postings for goods movements of UNBW materials.

SAP EWM: Still requires a product master and stock representation. Non‚Äëvaluated products behave like normal stock logistically (putaway, picking, bin management). Difference: No valuation integration with MM/FI. EWM tracks quantities for warehouse operations but doesn‚Äôt push value postings to MM.

Text Items in SAP EWM
Definition: Items in a delivery or warehouse request that are purely descriptive.
System behavior: No product master required.
Do not create deliveries, warehouse tasks, or stock movements.
Used for notes, instructions, or references (e.g., ‚ÄúHandle with care‚Äù or ‚ÄúCustomer request‚Äù).

They can appear in delivery documents but remain informational. No exceptions‚Äîtext items never trigger logistics execution.

Hope my explanation is fine for your understanding. if you have any more question, feel free to ask. if satisfied then confirm.

entry.title: Re: Long text formatting options - editor
entry.content:
Hi @isabelle1993 ,

That's true, SAP allows some flexibility in replacing or improving the long text editor. You can configure whether the editor uses the standard SAP GUI editor, the MS Word-based editor, or other text-based options. However, replacing the editor entirely is limited to what SAP provides‚Äîcustomization usually involves adjusting system settings, user parameters, or using Business Client integration rather than installing a completely new editor
To solve your issue, I suggest standardizing on one editor (preferably the line editor for consistency) and using ABAP enhancements to normalize line breaks before texts are passed to subsequent systems. If you want to explore editor settings, check SAP GUI options under Utilities ‚Üí Settings ‚Üí Word Processing or consult your Basis team to enforce editor consistency.

entry.title: SAPUI5 Rich Text Editor Custom File & Image Upload Handler
entry.content:
Introduction

If you‚Äôve ever built a comments, notes, approvals, or collaboration feature in SAPUI5 using sap.ui.richtexteditor.RichTextEditor, you‚Äôve probably faced this problem:

  • Users paste screenshots or images
  • TinyMCE embeds them as base64 blobs
  • Database size, payloads, and performance quickly degrade

Additionally, there is no native support for attaching documents such as PDFs or Excel files in a clean, enterprise-friendly way.

In real-world SAP applications, we usually want:

  • Images stored in the backend and referenced via URLs
  • Documents uploaded separately and inserted as download links
  • Automatic cleanup of unused images and attachments
  • Lightweight and performant HTML stored in the database

This blog explains a production-ready approach to extending SAPUI5 RichTextEditor (TinyMCE 7) to achieve exactly that.

What We‚Äôll Build

By the end of this guide, your RichTextEditor will be able to:

  • Convert pasted or inserted images from base64 ‚Üí backend URLs
  • Upload non-image files (PDF, DOCX, XLS, etc.)
  • Insert attachments as downloadable links at the cursor position
  • Automatically clean up orphaned images and files on save

All of this using:

  • TinyMCE hooks via beforeEditorInit

  • SAPUI5 + TypeScript

  • OData V4 entities (Comment, Image, Attachment)

High-Level Architecture

At a conceptual level, we separate responsibilities clearly:

  • Comment ‚Äì Stores the rich text HTML content
  • Image ‚Äì Stores image metadata and binary stream
  • Attachment ‚Äì Stores document metadata and binary stream

The RichTextEditor stores only URLs, never raw binary data.

Note on Backend Entity Design

Important: The Comment, Image, and Attachment entities shown in this blog are purely illustrative and created only for demonstration purposes.

You are free to structure, merge, or normalize these entities based on your own domain model, security requirements, or performance considerations. The concepts demonstrated remain the same.

RichTextEditor Initialization (View & Controller)

RichTextEditor Setup in the View

The editor is configured to use TinyMCE 7 with a custom toolbar and an additional file upload button. Visibility is controlled via an Edit/Display mode flag.

<ri:RichTextEditor
  id="idContentRichTextEditor"
  editable="true"
  width="100%"
  height="90%"
  editorType="TinyMCE7"
  showGroupFont="true"
  showGroupLink="true"
  showGroupInsert="false"
  showGroupUndo="true"
  showGroupClipboard="false"
  showGroupStructure="true"
  customToolbar="true"
  visible="{= ${/mode} === 'Edit'}">

  <ri:customButtons>
    <Button
      id="idUploadFileButton"
      text="Upload File"
      icon="sap-icon://attachment"
      press="onUploadFileButtonPress"/>
  </ri:customButtons>

</ri:RichTextEditor>
<!-- Hidden file input for image upload -->
<core:HTML content="<input type='file' id='hiddenFileInput' accept='.doc,.docx,.xls,.xlsx,.pdf ' style='display:none;'/>" />

Runtime Initialization in onAfterRendering

The editor lifecycle is initialized in onAfterRendering to ensure that:

  • The view model is initialized
  • TinyMCE hooks are attached only once
  • A backend Comment entity exists before uploads begin
public async onAfterRendering(): Promise<void> {

  const oModel = new JSONModel({
    mode: 'Edit',
    content: ''
  });
  this.getView().setModel(oModel);

  this.getView()
    .byId('idContentRichTextEditor')
    .attachEventOnce(
      'beforeEditorInit',
      this.onBeforeEditorInit.bind(this)
    );

  const response = await fetch('/odata/v4/editor/Comment', {
    method: 'POST',
    headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
    body: JSON.stringify({ content: 'Initial comment' })
  });

  if (response.ok) {
    const result = await response.json();
    this.commentId = result.ID;
    await this.loadCommentContent();
  } else {
    console.error('Failed to create comment');
  }
}

Injecting TinyMCE Configuration

SAPUI5 allows us to hook into TinyMCE initialization using beforeEditorInit. This is the key extension point.

Here, we:

  • Enable image paste support
  • Disable automatic base64 uploads
  • Inject a custom image upload handler
private onBeforeEditorInit(oEvent: Event): void {
  const params: any = (oEvent as any).getParameters();

  params.settings = {
    plugins: 'link image paste',
    paste_data_images: true,
    automatic_uploads: false,
    images_upload_handler: async (blobInfo, success, failure) => {
      try {
        await this.handleImageUpload(blobInfo, success, failure);
      } catch (e: any) {
        failure(e?.message || 'Upload failed');
      }
    }
  };
}

Handling Image Uploads (Replacing Base64)

When a user pastes an image:

  1. TinyMCE gives us the image as a Blob

  2. We create a backend Image entity

  3. Upload the binary stream

  4. Replace the base64 src with a relative backend URL using the success method handler.

 

private async handleImageUpload(
  blobInfo: any,
  success: (url: string) => void,
  failure: (err: string) => void
): Promise<void> {

  const blob = blobInfo.blob();
  const filename = blobInfo.filename();

  const metaRes = await fetch('/odata/v4/editor/Image', {
    method: 'POST',
    headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
    body: JSON.stringify({
      fileName: filename,
      comment_ID: this.commentId
    })
  });

  if (!metaRes.ok) {
    failure('Meta create failed');
    return;
  }

  const meta = await metaRes.json();

  await fetch(`/odata/v4/editor/Image(${meta.ID})/imageData`, {
    method: 'PUT',
    headers: { 'Content-Type': blob.type || 'image/png' },
    body: blob
  });

  success(`/odata/v4/editor/Image(${meta.ID})/imageData`);
}

Uploading Attachments and Inserting Download Links

mages are only half the story. Enterprise users expect to attach documents.

We added a custom toolbar button to the RichTextEditor and a hidden <input type="file"> handles file selection.

Uploading Attachments

The attachment flow mirrors images:

  1. Create metadata

  2. Upload binary

  3. Insert a clickable link

 

 private onUploadFileButtonPress(): void {
    const hiddenInput = document.getElementById(
      'hiddenFileInput'
    ) as HTMLInputElement;
    if (hiddenInput) {
      // Update accept attribute to include more file types
      hiddenInput.accept =
        '.doc,.docx,.xls,.xlsx,.pdf,.txt,.png,.jpg,.jpeg,.gif';

      hiddenInput.onchange = (event: any) => {
        const files = event.target.files;
        if (files && files.length > 0) {
          this.handleAttachmentUpload(files[0]);
        }
        // Clear the input so the same file can be selected again
        hiddenInput.value = '';
      };
      hiddenInput.click();
    }
  }

  private async handleAttachmentUpload(file: File): Promise<void> {
    try {
      // First create the attachment record
      const response = await fetch('/odata/v4/editor/Attachment', {
        method: 'POST',
        body: JSON.stringify({
          fileName: file.name,
          fileSize: file.size,
          mimeType: file.type,
          comment_ID: this.commentId,
        }),
        headers: {
          'Content-Type': 'application/json',
        },
      });

      if (!response.ok) {
        console.error('Failed to create attachment record');
        return;
      }

      const result = await response.json();
      const attachmentId = result.ID;

      // Upload the actual file data
      const uploadResponse = await fetch(
        `/odata/v4/editor/Attachment(${attachmentId})/attachmentData`,
        {
          method: 'PUT',
          body: file,
          headers: {
            'Content-Type': file.type || 'application/octet-stream',
          },
        }
      );

      if (uploadResponse.ok) {
        const attachmentUrl = `/odata/v4/editor/Attachment(${attachmentId})/attachmentData`;

        // Insert anchor tag into the rich text editor
        this.insertAttachmentLink(file.name, attachmentUrl);
      } else {
        console.error('Attachment upload failed');
      }
    } catch (error) {
      console.error('Attachment upload error:', error);
    }
  }

And then insert the link at the cursor position:

private insertAttachmentLink(fileName: string, attachmentUrl: string): void {
    const richTextEditor = this.getView().byId(
      'idContentRichTextEditor'
    ) as any;
    const nativeApi = richTextEditor.getNativeApi();

    if (nativeApi) {
      // Create the anchor tag HTML
      const anchorHtml = `<a href="${attachmentUrl}" download="${fileName}" target="_blank">${fileName}</a> `;

      nativeApi.execCommand('mceInsertContent', false, anchorHtml);
    }
  }

Now users get a clean, intuitive UX for documents.

Cleaning Up Orphaned Images and Attachments

One often-missed problem:
What happens when users remove images or links before saving?

Without cleanup, your backend fills up with unused binaries.

Solution:

  • Parse the HTML on save

  • Extract referenced IDs

  • Compare with DB

  • Delete unused records

private async onSaveButtonPress(): void {
    const richTextEditor = this.getView().byId(
      'idContentRichTextEditor'
    ) as any;
    const content = richTextEditor.getValue();

    // Extract IDs from current content
    const currentImageIds = this.extractImageSources(content);
    const currentAttachmentIds = this.extractAttachmentSources(content);

    try {
      // Get all images associated with this comment from database
      const imageResponse = await fetch(
        '/odata/v4/editor/Image?$filter=comment_ID%20eq%20%27' +
          this.commentId +
          '%27',
        {
          method: 'GET',
        }
      );

      let dbImageIds: string[] = [];
      if (imageResponse.ok) {
        const imageResult = await imageResponse.json();
        dbImageIds = imageResult.value.map((img: any) => img.ID);
      }

      // Get all attachments associated with this comment from database
      const attachmentResponse = await fetch(
        '/odata/v4/editor/Attachment?$filter=comment_ID%20eq%20%27' +
          this.commentId +
          '%27',
        {
          method: 'GET',
        }
      );

      let dbAttachmentIds: string[] = [];
      if (attachmentResponse.ok) {
        const attachmentResult = await attachmentResponse.json();
        dbAttachmentIds = attachmentResult.value.map((att: any) => att.ID);
      }

      // Find unused images (in DB but not in content)
      const unusedImageIds = dbImageIds.filter(
        (id) => !currentImageIds.includes(id)
      );

      // Find unused attachments (in DB but not in content)
      const unusedAttachmentIds = dbAttachmentIds.filter(
        (id) => !currentAttachmentIds.includes(id)
      );

      // Delete unused images
      for (const imageId of unusedImageIds) {
        try {
          const deleteResponse = await fetch(
            `/odata/v4/editor/Image(${imageId})`,
            {
              method: 'DELETE',
            }
          );
        } catch (error) {
          console.error(`Error deleting image ${imageId}:`, error);
        }
      }

      // Delete unused attachments
      for (const attachmentId of unusedAttachmentIds) {
        try {
          const deleteResponse = await fetch(
            `/odata/v4/editor/Attachment(${attachmentId})`,
            {
              method: 'DELETE',
            }
          );
        } catch (error) {
          console.error(`Error deleting attachment ${attachmentId}:`, error);
        }
      }

      // Save the comment content
      const saveResponse = await fetch(
        `/odata/v4/editor/Comment(${this.commentId})`,
        {
          method: 'PATCH',
          body: JSON.stringify({
            content: content,
          }),
          headers: {
            'Content-Type': 'application/json',
          },
        }
      );

      if (saveResponse.ok) {
        // Show success message to user
        const messageToast = await import('sap/m/MessageToast');
        messageToast.default.show('Comment saved successfully!');
      } else {
        console.error('Failed to save comment');

        // Show error message to user
        const messageToast = await import('sap/m/MessageToast');
        messageToast.default.show('Failed to save comment. Please try again.');
      }
    } catch (error) {
      console.error('Error during save process:', error);

      // Show error message to user
      const messageToast = await import('sap/m/MessageToast');
      messageToast.default.show(
        'An error occurred while saving. Please try again.'
      );
    }
  }

  // Add the missing extractAttachmentSources method
  private extractAttachmentSources(htmlContent: string): string[] {
    const hrefRegex = /<a[^>]+href="([^"]+)"[^>]*>/gi;
    const attachmentIds: string[] = [];
    let match;

    while ((match = hrefRegex.exec(htmlContent)) !== null) {
      const hrefUrl = match[1];

      // Extract ID from URL pattern: /odata/v4/editor/Attachment(ID)/attachmentData
      const idMatch = hrefUrl.match(
        /\/odata\/v4\/editor\/Attachment\(([^)]+)\)\/attachmentData/
      );

      if (idMatch && idMatch[1]) {
        attachmentIds.push(idMatch[1]);
      }
    }

    return attachmentIds;
  }

  private extractImageSources(htmlContent: string): string[] {
    const srcRegex = /<img[^>]+src="([^"]+)"/gi;
    const imageIds: string[] = [];
    let match;

    while ((match = srcRegex.exec(htmlContent)) !== null) {
      const srcUrl = match[1];

      // Extract ID from URL pattern: /odata/v4/editor/Image(ID)/imageData
      const idMatch = srcUrl.match(
        /\/odata\/v4\/editor\/Image\(([^)]+)\)\/imageData/
      );

      if (idMatch && idMatch[1]) {
        imageIds.push(idMatch[1]);
      }
    }

    return imageIds;
  }

Edit vs Display Mode

A common pattern is:

  • Edit mode ‚Äì RichTextEditor
  • Display mode ‚Äì core:HTML or FormattedText

Always sanitize HTML on the server side when rendering user-generated content.

Key Benefits of This Approach

  • No base64 blobs in your database
  • Faster load times and smaller payloads
  • Clean separation of content and binaries
  • Automatic lifecycle management
  • Enterprise-grade UX for documents and images

Optional Enhancements

You can easily extend this further:

  • Upload progress indicators

  • Drag & drop file support

  • Batch cleanup using OData $batch

  • Virus scanning or file-type validation

Conclusion

SAPUI5‚Äôs RichTextEditor combined with TinyMCE 7 is powerful‚Äîbut only when extended correctly.

By leveraging TinyMCE hooks, custom upload handlers, and a simple OData-backed storage model, you can build a robust, scalable, and clean solution for handling pasted images and file attachments in SAPUI5 applications.

If you‚Äôre building any serious enterprise UI with rich text, this pattern is well worth adopting.

entry.title: Re: purchase order text not updating in BAPI_material_Sav...
entry.content:
Hi @tadao_ando ,

I understand your issue as its one of the limitation of BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA and BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEREPLICA when trying to update PO text (Purchasing text). The error message MG 157 ‚ÄúPO text cannot be edited‚Äù usually means the BAPI is not the right interface for that field, because PO texts are technically handled as long texts in SAP, not as part of the material master core segments.

This if happening because BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA only updates material master data (basic data, purchasing views, sales views, etc.), but long texts like PO text are stored separately in STXH/STXL tables and managed via SAPscript / Smartform text objects. The PO text is linked to material master but technically maintained via text object MATERIAL and text ID BEST (Purchasing). That‚Äôs why you see intermittent success ‚Äî sometimes the proxy passes the text correctly, but often the BAPI ignores or rejects it.

Use SAVE_TEXT / CREATE_TEXT function modules, These are designed to update long texts. You can call SAVE_TEXT after your BAPI call to ensure the PO text is written. Text object: MATERIAL, Text ID: BEST, Language: EN (or relevant). Then commit with COMMIT WORK.

Use BAPI_SERVICE_TEXTS or BAPI_MATERIAL_GETTEXTS / BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVE_TEXTS. SAP provides text-specific BAPIs for material texts. BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVE_TEXTS is the clean alternative to update PO texts without hitting the MG 157 error.

Batch Input / LSMW (fallback) If you need mass updates and BAPI doesn‚Äôt cover your scenario, a batch input recording (transaction MM02 ‚Üí Purchasing view ‚Üí PO text) can be used.

You can also use Enhancement / BAdI
If you must stick with BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA, you can enhance it via BAdI BADI_MATERIAL_REF or BADI_MATERIAL_MASTER to hook in text updates.
This way, the BAPI call triggers your custom logic to update PO texts via SAVE_TEXT.

Hope your issue has been resolve, if yes confirm or let me know if you get any other error

entry.title: Securing Enterprise AI on SAP BTP: Zero Trust Authentication with SAP AI Core
entry.content:
(Jana Subramanian serves as Head of Cybersecurity and Compliance for SEA and is a Fellow of Information Privacy (FIP), awarded by the International Association of Privacy Professionals (IAPP). In this role, Jana supports strategic customer engagements on cybersecurity, data privacy, multi-cloud security integration architecture, contractual assurance, audit, and compliance.)

Introduction:

If you are building AI-powered applications on SAP BTP with SAP AI Core, understanding how authentication works is essential. This blog walks through the complete SAML-to-OAuth flow from corporate SSO to securely calling AI services, using simple diagrams and clear explanations. Along the way, we also clarify common misconceptions about SAML assertions, token handling, and why your application never deals with SAML directly.

This post does not cover detailed configuration steps. Instead, it focuses on the high-level concepts and end-to-end flow to help you build a clear mental model of how authentication works in SAP BTP.  By the end, you will understand the overall process from user login to AI inference, illustrated step-by-step for easier comprehension.

Step: 1

User Enters Application URL The authentication journey begins when a user opens their web browser and enters the URL for the SAP BTP application. At this initial stage, the user is unauthenticated, and the browser sends an HTTP GET request (unauthenticated at this stage). This step represents the standard entry point where the user knocks on the door of the application before any security checks are applied.

Step 2:

Traffic Reaches App Router / Application Once the traffic reaches the SAP BTP Application (or App Router), the component acts as a security gatekeeper. It immediately inspects the request to see if a valid session or OAuth 2.0 JWT token already exists. In this scenario, because it is a new login attempt, no valid token is found, and the application recognizes that it must initiate the authentication process to protect its resources .

Step 3:

Application Redirects to XSUAA Instead of handling authentication itself or sending the user directly to the corporate Identity Provider, the application redirects the user's browser to XSUAA, the platform's OAuth 2.0 Authorization Server. This is a critical architectural design: the application initiates a standard OAuth Authorization Code Flow, effectively delegating all complexity regarding SAML and corporate identity to XSUAA.

Step 4:

XSUAA Generates SAML AuthnRequest & Redirects to IdP XSUAA now takes over the orchestration by generating a SAML Authentication Request (AuthnRequest) and redirecting the user's browser to the corporate Identity Provider (IdP), such as Azure AD or Okta . By handling this step, XSUAA acts as the Service Provider on behalf of the application, managing the trust configuration and specific SAML protocol requirements so the application doesn't have to.

Step 5:

Authenticates User and Issues SAML Assertion The user completes their login at the corporate IdP (using passwords or MFA), and upon success, the IdP generates a cryptographically signed SAML assertion . Crucially, the browser POSTs this assertion directly to XSUAA's Assertion Consumer Service (ACS) endpoint‚Äînot to the application. This ensures the application never touches the XML or handles the certificate validation, keeping the application logic clean and secure.

Step 6:

XSUAA Performs SAML to OAuth Token Exchange Upon receiving the SAML assertion, XSUAA validates the digital signature and timestamps, and automatically maps the SAML attributes to OAuth scopes . Once validation passes, XSUAA generates an OAuth 2.0 authorization code and redirects the browser back to the application's callback URL with this code in the query string . This step effectively translates the enterprise SAML identity into a modern OAuth artifact transparently.

Step 7:

Application Exchanges Authorization Code for OAuth Tokens The application receives the authorization code and immediately performs a secure, server-to-server POST request to XSUAA to exchange it for an access token and a refresh token . Because this request includes the application's Client ID and Client Secret, XSUAA verifies the application's identity before issuing the tokens, which are then stored securely in the server-side session .

Step 8:

Application Calls GenAI Hub API Using Access Token With a valid OAuth access token securely stored, the SAP BTP application can now invoke the Generative AI Hub. To do this, the application sends an HTTP request‚Äîtypically a POST‚Äîto the GenAI Hub API endpoint containing the user‚Äôs input or inference prompt. The most important part of this request is the Authorization header, where the application includes the JWT access token using the standard OAuth bearer format (Authorization: Bearer <JWT>) . This step represents the handoff from authentication to operation: the application is no longer proving identity but instead using the validated token to access protected AI services. The GenAI Hub will then independently validate the JWT before forwarding the request to SAP AI Core for model execution.

Step 9:

Gen AI Hub Validates JWT LOCALLY When the application makes an API call to the Gen AI Hub using the access token, the Hub validates the token locally rather than calling back to XSUAA . By using cached public keys (JWKS) from XSUAA, Gen AI Hub can instantly verify the token's signature, expiration, and scopes . This local validation approach significantly reduces latency (from ~100ms to ~10ms) while maintaining cryptographic security.

Step 10

AI Core Independently Validates JWT (Zero Trust) Adhering to Zero Trust principles, when Gen AI Hub forwards the request to SAP AI Core, AI Core does not blindly trust the previous validation . Instead, it independently validates the token again using the same local JWKS method to verify the signature and ensure the user has the specific permissions required for the target resource group . This defense-in-depth strategy ensures that even if an upstream service were compromised, unauthorized access is prevented.

Step 11:

Response Returns to User After the AI Core executes the inference on the model, the results travel back up the chain‚Äîfrom AI Core to Gen AI Hub, and finally to the application . The application receives the AI-generated response and renders it to the user interface. The user sees the result immediately, completely unaware of the sophisticated "authentication dance" and multi-layered security checks that occurred in the background.

Complete Authentication and Authorization Flow:

The complete architecture brings all these components together, visualizing the robust interplay between the User, App Router, XSUAA, Identity Provider, and AI services. It highlights the separation of concerns where XSUAA manages identity federation, the application handles business logic via OAuth, and the backend AI services enforce security through independent, local Zero Trust validation.

If you still have a challenge in understanding technicalities, here is a layman point of view for better comprehension:

  1. You want to enter the building (BTP App)
  2. Security guard (App Router) says "Show me your badge"
  3. You don't have one, so guard sends you to Badge Office (XSUAA)
  4. Badge Office says "Prove you work here - go to HR (IdP)"
  5. HR checks your ID (username/password + MFA)
  6. HR gives you a signed letter (SAML) for Badge Office
  7. Badge Office checks HR's signature ‚úì
  8. Badge Office gives you a CLAIM TICKET (authorization code) - NOT the badge yet!
  9. You give the claim ticket to the guard (App Router)
  10. Guard takes your claim ticket + their secret password to Badge Office
  11. Badge Office verifies claim ticket + guard's credentials
  12. Badge Office NOW gives the guard your access badge (OAuth token)
  13. Guard stores your badge securely and lets you in
  14. Inside building, each room (Gen AI Hub, AI Core) scans your badge
  15. Each room verifies badge locally using master key
  16. You get access

Common Misconception

 

#

Misconception

Reality (Correct Explanation)

1

The application receives or processes the SAMLResponse.

The SAMLResponse is posted only to XSUAA (ACS endpoint). The application never interacts with SAML.

2

XSUAA forwards the SAML assertion to the application.

XSUAA converts the SAML assertion into an OAuth Authorization Code, then into JWT tokens. No SAML leaves XSUAA.

3

SAP BTP applications authenticate directly with the IdP.

Apps authenticate only with XSUAA, not the IdP. The IdP authenticates users, not applications.

4

GenAI Hub or AI Core call XSUAA to validate JWTs.

Both services validate tokens locally using JWKS. No introspection call is made to XSUAA.

5

AI Core does not need to revalidate the JWT if GenAI Hub validated it already.

AI Core enforces Zero Trust and performs its own independent JWT validation.

6

OAuth Authorization Codes are long-lived.

Authorization Codes are short-lived (seconds) and single-use only.

7

Token lifetimes are fixed and universal.

Token lifetimes (access/refresh/session) are configurable per subaccount or client.

8

JWTs contain passwords or sensitive authentication data.

JWTs include claims only (audience, scopes, expiry, user ID). Credentials and MFA data never appear inside a token.

9

OAuth tokens are returned through browser redirects.

Token exchange happens only server-side between the app backend and XSUAA. Tokens never travel in URLs.

10

GenAI Hub or AI Core receive SAML attributes.

Downstream services receive JWT scopes, not SAML attributes. SAML-to-scope mapping happens in XSUAA.

11

The application should call AI Core directly.

Best practice: App ‚Üí GenAI Hub ‚Üí AI Core. GenAI Hub manages token validation, routing, and observability.

12

Refresh tokens are always issued.

Refresh tokens are issued only if allowed by the OAuth client configuration.

13

The IdP decides which OAuth scopes the app gets.

IdP only provides identity attributes. XSUAA assigns scopes based on role collections and SAML group mappings.

14

SAML and OAuth are separate flows.

They form a single chained flow: SAML user authentication ‚Üí XSUAA ‚Üí OAuth token issuance ‚Üí JWT for APIs.

Key Benefits

 

Benefit

Why It Matters

How the Architecture Enables It

1. Clear Separation of Concerns

Reduces application complexity and security risk.

XSUAA absorbs all SAML, federation, and identity-provider logic; applications speak only OAuth.

2. Seamless Single Sign-On (SSO)

Smooth user experience with no repeated logins.

SAML authentication happens once via the corporate IdP; OAuth tokens propagate downstream automatically.

3. Zero Trust Validation

Ensures no service blindly trusts another‚Äîimproves overall security posture.

GenAI Hub and AI Core independently validate JWTs locally using JWKS.

4. Defense-in-Depth Security

Multiple layers of verification block misuse even if one component is compromised.

SAML assertions validated at XSUAA ‚Üí JWT validated at GenAI Hub ‚Üí validated again at AI Core.

5. No Exposure of SAML to Applications

Prevents incorrect handling of complex SAML logic by developers.

All SAML exchanges occur strictly between IdP and XSUAA (ACS endpoint).

6. Standards-Based Interoperability

Easier integration, maintainability, and compatibility with enterprise systems.

Uses industry standards (SAML 2.0, OAuth 2.0, JWT, JWKS).

7. High Performance Token Validation

Reduces network latency and improves inference speed.

Local JWT validation avoids calls back to XSUAA for each request.

8. Scalability Across Services

Allows multiple SAP services to trust the same identity securely.

A single JWT can be validated independently by GenAI Hub and AI Core.

9. Strong Cryptographic Guarantees

Protects against tampering, interception, and replay attacks.

Signed SAMLResponse + signed JWT + short-lived authorization codes.

10. Invisible Complexity for End Users

Users face no friction, even though the architecture is advanced.

Redirects, token exchanges, and validations happen fully behind the scenes.

11. Centralized Identity Governance

Simplifies role management and compliance.

XSUAA handles role collections, scope assignment, and mapping from IdP attributes.

12. Clean Application Code

Faster development, fewer bugs, and clearer security boundaries.

Application deals only with Bearer tokens‚Äînever SAML assertions or IdP protocols.

 

Conclusion

We have now traced the complete lifecycle of a request starting from a simple browser click and ending with a sophisticated AI inference. The elegance of this architecture lies in its separation of concerns. XSUAA handles the heavy lifting by absorbing all the complexity of SAML and corporate identity federation, allowing your application to stay clean and focused, speaking only standard OAuth. Just as important, security on SAP BTP is not a single gate check. Through local JWT validation and Zero Trust principles, services such as the Generative AI Hub and SAP AI Core independently verify every incoming request using cached public signing keys. This provides true defense in depth without compromising performance.

For the end user, all of this, redirects, token exchanges, validations, and cryptographic guarantees, remains completely transparent. They log in once and simply get to work. By understanding the rationale behind these architectural diagrams, it is easier to design SAP Business AI driven applications that are operationally robust and secure by design.

entry.title: My Experience with the New SAP Exam Format¬†(2026)
entry.content:
Starting from November 2025, SAP officially introduced a significant change to its certification journey: an open-book, scenario-based exam format. This new approach is currently in pilot for selected certifications, including the SAP BTP Solution Architect exam.

Details about format here: Reimagining certification in the age of AI

Last week, I had the chance to take this new exam for the certificate ‚ÄúSAP BTP Solution Architect‚Äù and I want to share my honest experience, especially for those preparing for it soon.

After reading the new update from SAP (above link), I learn some more details in a blog in SAP community:

How to Prepare for SAP‚Äôs New Certification‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäSAP Community

However, it‚Äôs still not very clear for me how it looks like in the actual exam. So I gave it a try. For the ‚ÄúSAP BTP Solution Architect‚Äù, it‚Äôs a ‚Äúscenario-based‚Äù exam format, where you need to play the role of a solution architect, designing the solution for a use case, then pitch the solution to AI avatar, or record a video and upload for expert review.

Unlike the previous exam format, where you need to setup some software (private browser) to take a prottor-monitored multiple-choice exam, in this new format, you will start directly from SAP learning website. This is the first look at the new exam format.

(To have this view, you must have purchased the SAP Certification Subcription; I will share in another post)

SAP Certificate landing page, where you can start the exam

After pressing on the ‚ÄúGo to Certification Exam‚Äù, the website will open a wizard like dialog to guide you through the process, which is quite user friendly:

SAP Certification Exam‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäScenario Based Assessment‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäAI Roleplay

For the exam of ‚ÄúSolution Architect‚Äù, you will be assigned to a use case, where you play the architect role to propose a solution to project stakeholders. The use case resembles the actual use case in one project.

For example, in my exam, I need to design a soluton for Field Service Maintainance Engineer to efficiently get and update data with S/4 systems, while they‚Äôre working at customer site.

After reading the use case, once you‚Äôre ready, you can choose 1 out of 2 options to proceed with the pitching part.

For the next step, you will have 2 options to join the xam:

  • AI Roleplay with AI Guidance.
  • Record Video with Human Review.

I tried both, and share my experience as below:

1. A Fresh Concept: Scenario-Based + AI Roleplay

The most exciting part of the new format is the ‚ÄúRoleplay with AI‚Äù feature. Instead of answering static questions, you interact with an AI avatar acting as your stakeholder, and you must propose and justify your architecture on SAP BTP.

This idea is brilliant‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit mimics real project work and tests your ability to think, design, and explain like a true architect.

However‚Ä¶ the reality wasn‚Äôt as smooth as expected.

2. Technical Issues: The AI Mode Was Not Stable

Despite an impressive concept, the AI roleplay mode repeatedly failed during my attempts. I tried everything:

  • Company laptop and personal MacBook
  • Corporate network, home Wi-Fi, mobile hotspot
  • Multiple browsers and system setups

Yet the final step always returned the same message:

‚ÄúAn error occurred. Please refresh the page and try again. If the issue persists, contact the support team for assistance.‚Äù

AI Roleplay option‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääerror

The other option with Human review also didn‚Äôt work:

Human review option‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääerror

Since SAP requires exam submission within 24 hours, the pressure was real. I opened a support ticket, but even after a full working day, there was no response.

3. The Backup Plan: Human Review

Fortunately, late in the day, one of my setups finally allowed me to switch to the ‚ÄúTraditional Assessment‚Äù option, with human review my recording. This required me to:

  • Record and upload a video explaining my architecture
  • Wait for a manual evaluation by an SAP expert

For this option, things are very ‚Äúgeneric‚Äù. SAP does not provides any details on the expectation of the video. All you can do is to prepare the best solution, and present it, during the 2 hours period.

After submitting your video, you will get the result immediately with the AI Roleplace approach. But with the human review approach, you will need to wait for a long time to get the result. During this period, if you enter the certification page again, you will get the ‚ÄúIn Review‚Äù status:

 

The downside?
 The waiting time for results is now 20 days.
 This delay is a huge gap in the expectation of exam taker in this fast-paced world.

4. Final Thoughts: Great Idea, but Needs Stability

I truly appreciate SAP‚Äôs direction. A scenario-based, open-book exam that simulates real project challenges is the right way forward. It evaluates real skills‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänot memorization.

But the instability of the AI mode currently holds back the full potential of this format. When candidates must fall back to manual review, the process becomes:

  • Slow
  • Costly
  • Frustrating
  • Uncertain

For exam takers, waiting nearly a month for results is a painful experience.

5. Looking Ahead

I hope SAP can quickly stabilize the AI roleplay feature. When it works, it will elevate the certification experience and set a new benchmark for professional exams.

The concept is powerful.
 The execution just needs more refinement.

And once it‚Äôs stable, I believe this format will truly redefine how SAP professionals prove their expertise in the future.

entry.title: RAP : Managed with Unmanaged Save with Draft handling Create Mode issue
entry.content:
Hi All,
I have created a Managed app with unmanaged save having code to trigger BAPI to save transactional data.  I have added draft functionality to this app and all works find except for create mode. 

I am able to update root and dependent child node details successfully but when a new Document is created  or a new line item is added to associated child note, I get below error - 

The handler implementation for early numbering returned neither a FAILED nor a MAPPED response for a specific input instance.

I checked the various methods and MAPPED and FAILED table is updated successfully.  Few observations :
1. During create mode earlynumbering_create method is triggered twice and MAPPED table is populated twice 

2. On clicking Save, Method save_modified create does not return any data in importing parameter CREATE  so BAPI is not triggered and CHANGING parameter reported is also not filled by custom logic.

Could you please suggest if you have came across such issues and solution for the same. 

Thanks !!

entry.title: Re: The Re-emergence of Community in the SAP Ecosystem
entry.content:
Nice post, Chris, and yes, I agree with your observation (also shared by Ben) about the classic "hallway track" and how the interstitial conversations are often the most valuable. I think the catalyst for such ad hoc get-togethers was the length of time it's been since the previous in-person event in Europe; folks were just pulled together by the magnetism of being able to reunite, but then stayed talking to share experiences that they've not been able to do (for whatever reasons) online over the past few years. And face to face always trumps virtual when it comes to talking.

Your comments remind me of the un-conferences I've been to in the past, flavours from which were in the Community Theatre in Berlin, which I'd love to see take an even bigger role and presence next time.

entry.title: How-To build BW BEx User/Customer Exits in Datasphere (DSP) / SAC
entry.content:
Basic:

In traditional SAP BW, User/Customer Exits allow for centrally managed code that applies to all BEx queries. An efficient, object-oriented approach. This functionality can be built via SAC's Composite Widgets (CW). The main / common functions such as ISO-week, Fiscal YearPeriod, Project specific functions, can be placed into a single / multiple CWs. These CWs will be added to Stories and the Stories can use the CWs ‚Äì Interfaces (Public-like Methods). CWs use also own functions (Private-like Methods). This approach allows to have all the functions in one place.

 

Use cases:

This solution can be used to centralize and standardize various functions across multiple SAC stories, including:

  • A universal on/off switch for JavaScript logging. Logs are critical for troubleshooting, but also slow down the processing a bit and can provide unwanted details to end-users.
  • A custom function to calculate the ISO Week (not supported by default in SAC optimized stories).
  • Automatic calculation of the current fiscal period based on the current date.
  • A global "maintenance switch" to manage functionalities during version rollouts. Possible to route to an Out-Of-Order Story.
  • Displaying the data loading status from Datasphere.

 

How-To:

  • Create a composite (e.g. COMMON_FUNCTIONS) and move common JavaScript and functions from individual stories into this composite.
  • Expose functionality via interfaces (public) and keep helper logic as Functions (private methods) inside the composite.
  • Add the composite to each required story/page via drag & drop, hide it at design/runtime, and call its interfaces as if they were local story functions.
  • For configuration/switches (similar to TVARVC/P-tables), use SAC acquired models‚Äîoptionally loaded from DSP via OData‚Äîfor better performance than live connections.
  • Be aware of library limits inside composites (e.g. Application.getUser()), and pass required context (user, filters, etc.) from the story into the composite.

Possible only with SAC (native or seamless) planning:

Direct write-back from a Story (f.e. last used prompt). This part is not covered as planning is usually limited in SAC due to extra licensing as in BW/4.

entry.title: SAP SuccessFactors Go-Live Readiness: The Practical Playbook for a Safe Launch
entry.content:
The SuccessFactors Go-Live Readiness Guide

A practical guide to protect business operations in Week 1 and beyond

Go-live is not an IT milestone. It‚Äôs a business continuity event.
On Day 1, SAP SuccessFactors becomes part of payroll deadlines, onboarding commitments, approvals, compliance, and leadership reporting.

This blog is designed to be a go/no-go reference you can reuse across programs : focused on what actually breaks in production and what to do about it.

TL;DR (Executive Summary)

A go-live is ‚Äúready‚Äù when five conditions are true:

  1. Tasks work (critical processes complete end-to-end)

  2. Data trusted (fit for HR operations + decisions)

  3. Payroll protected (timing/deltas/retries controlled)

  4. Access correct (right roles, no blockers, no overexposure)

  5. Support ready (issues resolved quickly without chaos)

If any of these are not true, expect Week-1 disruption.

 Go-live readiness is operational readiness

 

Who This Is For

  • Customers going live in the next 4‚Äì12 weeks

  • Program leads who need a business-owned readiness view

  • HR Ops, Payroll, and IT teams who want fewer surprises in Week 1

1) Scope Clarity: Prevent ‚ÄúSurprise Scope‚Äù on Day 1

Many Week-1 tickets are not defects, they‚Äôre expectation mismatches.

Lock down Day-1 scope like a contract

  • Modules + sub-features (e.g., EC core vs Position Management vs Time Off)

  • Population (countries/legal entities, contractors, executives)

  • Processes that must work Day 1

    • Hire / rehire / termination

    • Transfer / promotion / salary change

    • Manager change + delegation

    • Recruiting ‚Üí Onboarding ‚Üí EC hire (if applicable)

Non-negotiable deliverable (simple but powerful)

Create a one-page ‚ÄúDay-1 Capabilities Sheet‚Äù by role:

  • Employee / Manager / HR Admin / HRBP / Recruiter / Payroll

If it‚Äôs not written by role, it‚Äôs not understood by users.

2) Data Migration: Data Quality Is a Business Risk (Not a Technical Detail)

Bad data breaks trust faster than any UI issue.

What you must prove before go-live

  • At least two realistic mock loads (not sample loads)

  • Validation of outcomes, not only ‚Äúload succeeded‚Äù

  • Reconciliation that business accepts:

    • Headcount counts

    • Org/manager hierarchy

    • Job history sanity

    • Time off balances (if in scope)

    • Position relationships (if in scope)

Data Acceptance Criteria (example gates)

Use thresholds and hold the line:

  • 0 missing managers for active population

  • <0.5% org assignment exceptions

  • 100% active employees have user + email + manager

 Stoplights prevent ‚Äúwe‚Äôll fix it later‚Äù data debt.

 

3) RBP & Access: The #1 Go-Live Ticket Generator

If RBP is wrong, everything looks broken.

What to validate

  • All roles tested with day-in-the-life scenarios

  • Edge cases tested (they will happen):

    • Matrix managers

    • Delegates/coverage

    • HR supporting multiple entities

    • Country-specific sensitive access boundaries

  • Hypercare admins have required access (no dependency bottlenecks)

Practical mitigation (works every time)

Create a Role Test Pack:

  • 10 scenarios per role

  • executed by real business testers

  • with expected results + screenshots

Most access failures are predictable and preventable.

4) Workflows & Approvals: The Quiet Go-Live Killer

Workflows break due to missing approvers, permission gaps, and real-world org changes.

What ‚Äúworkflow ready‚Äù means

  • Every workflow has:

    • correct step owners

    • fallback paths

    • monitoring + ownership

  • You tested top transactions end-to-end:

    • Job changes

    • Terminations

    • Manager changes

    • Compensation approvals (if applicable)

    • Recruiting approvals (if applicable)

Practical mitigation: Workflow Rescue Kit (must-have)

Define:

  • who monitors stuck items

  • how to identify the failure reason quickly

  • who can fix data vs who can restart workflows

  • escalation within hours, not days

 When approvals stall, response time matters more than documentation.

 

5) Integrations: Test Reality (Timing + Volume), Not Just Mappings

Integrations fail on timing windows, dependencies, missed deltas, and lack of monitoring ownership.

What you must validate

  • End-to-end chain:

    • Recruiting ‚Üí Onboarding ‚Üí EC ‚Üí Payroll/IT provisioning

    • EC changes ‚Üí payroll/finance downstream

    • Termination ‚Üí downstream access removal

  • Operational readiness:

    • named owners per interface

    • alerts + logs

    • retry procedures

    • ‚Äúwhat if the file is late?‚Äù plan

Practical mitigation: Day-1 Integration Control Room

  • Hourly monitoring first 48‚Äì72 hours

  • Single tracker of failures + retries

  • Clear decision: ‚Äúmanual workaround vs wait for fix‚Äù

 

Monitor what can break payroll and onboarding first.

6) Reporting & Leadership Confidence: What Leaders Ask on Day 2

If leaders can‚Äôt trust numbers, they won‚Äôt trust the system.

Even when transactions work, credibility can collapse if reporting isn‚Äôt reliable.

Prepare a ‚ÄúDay-2 Reporting Pack‚Äù

Identify top questions and validate answers with real data:

  • Headcount by entity/country/location

  • New hires / exits this month

  • Open positions + stage distribution

  • Onboarding completion + blockers

  • Manager hierarchy accuracy

Practical mitigation: If definitions are not agreed, expect arguments instead of action. Publish metric definitions and owners.

7) Cutover: If You Didn‚Äôt Rehearse It, You Didn‚Äôt Plan It

Cutover is a timed dependency chain, not a checklist.

Minimum cutover requirements

  • Named owner per step + backup

  • Dependencies stated (‚Äúcannot start until X confirmed‚Äù)

  • Timed rehearsal (at least once)

  • Decision checkpoints (Go/No-Go gates)

Practical mitigation: Rehearse, measure durations, re-baseline the plan based on facts.

Gates prevent late surprises from becoming production incidents.

üòéHypercare: Design the Operating Model (Not Just a Team)

Hypercare fails when intake is scattered and priorities are unclear.

What strong hypercare looks like

  • One intake channel + categories

  • Daily triage call (short, disciplined)

  • Separate ‚Äúdefect‚Äù vs ‚Äúhow-to‚Äù

  • Named owners by domain:

    • EC data / workflows / RBP / integrations / Recruiting & Onboarding

  • Published response times for Week 1

Practical mitigation: Use a simple triage rule:

  • Payroll/onboarding blocker ‚Üí P1

  • Access preventing critical task ‚Üí P1

  • Incorrect data blocking operations ‚Üí P1/P2

  • How-to ‚Üí route to enablement (don‚Äôt bury the tech team)

Correct routing is your fastest Week-1 productivity gain.

Go/No-Go: Use Objective Gates (Not Optimism)

Go-live should not proceed unless these are true.

Go/No-Go Scorecard (sample)

Readiness Gate Must Be True Before Go Evidence Required Owner

Data AcceptanceThresholds metReconciliation report + sign-offHR Ops + Data Lead
RBPRoles tested end-to-endRole test pack resultsSecurity Lead
WorkflowsCore transactions passWorkflow test evidenceProcess Owner
IntegrationsMonitored + retryableControl room plan + test logsIntegration Lead
SupportHypercare readyRACI + runbooks + SLASupport Lead
Business AcceptanceRisks accepted in writingSigned risk registerBusiness Sponsor

If the business can‚Äôt sign it, it‚Äôs not a go-live decision

Week-1: What You Will See (and How to Contain It)

Even strong go-lives have issues. The goal is containment.

Likely Week-1 issues

  • Role/permission gaps for edge cases

  • Workflow routing failures for unusual org setups

  • Missed deltas / late integration files

  • Data corrections (manager/org/job info)

  • High volume ‚Äúhow-to‚Äù requests from managers

Containment tactics that actually work

  • Publish ‚ÄúKnown Issues + Workarounds‚Äù daily (short list)

  • Hourly monitoring for critical interfaces (first 72 hours)

  • Rapid, controlled access patch cycle (small changes, tracked)

  • Convert repeated ‚Äúhow-to‚Äù into 1-page guides immediately

Ticket volume peaks early. Discipline determines how fast it drops.

Week-1 Operating Plan (Copy/Paste)

Day 0 (Go-live day)

  • Validate login across roles

  • Validate manager sees team

  • Complete 3‚Äì5 sample transactions end-to-end

  • Start integration monitoring immediately

Days 1‚Äì2

  • Triage every 2‚Äì3 hours

  • Focus: RBP blockers, stuck workflows, integration failures

Days 3‚Äì5

  • Stabilize + remove recurring root causes

  • Convert repeated ‚Äúhow-to‚Äù into knowledge articles

  • Keep changes small, controlled, and documented

End of Week 1

  • Publish stabilization summary:

    • ticket volumes by category

    • root causes

    • fixes deployed

    • open risks + next steps

Closing Thought

If you want go-live to feel ‚Äúeasy,‚Äù don‚Äôt aim for perfect configuration. Aim for operational certainty:

  • users can complete tasks

  • data is trustworthy

  • approvals flow

  • integrations are monitored and owned

  • support resolves issues fast

Discussion!

Let me know what surprised you most in Week 1 after go-live : permissions, workflows, integrations, or reporting?

See you soon with a new blog!

entry.title: Re: Integrating ABAP system with SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
To setup the required communication arrangement, you need to have the administration role. Your screenshot shows (according to the offered tiles) that you have the development role, but not the administration role. 

There is exactly one trial environment, where connectivity setup is not supported: That is the Shared Trial option (see https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/it-s-trial-time-for-abap-in-sap-business-technology-platform/ba-p/13416047 and https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/get-started-with-sap-btp-abap-environment-trial-account-vs-free-tier-option/ba-p/13663694). Otherwise, other users of other companies could reuse your connectivity. 

In all other trial (free tier) and commercial environments you can get (technically) the administrator role and can setup connectivity.

For a client where GRPL is active and the system is on-premise, even though the RASSC field is filled in ACDOCA (as Q001), the RBUPTR field in ACDOCU is not populated.

The company code and partner company code details are as follows:
In the GUI, CoCd: 1000 and Company: 1000, CoCd: 1100 and Company: 1100, but the previously assigned trading partner is Q001 and Q002. Could this be the reason why the field is not being transferred?
If so, we cannot change this setup because, on the FI side, the structure is defined as CoCd: 1000 and Company: Q001 and CoCd: 1100 and Company: Q002

Is it possible to use a substitution in ACDOCU to map RASSC = RBUPTR?

You can find the ACDOCA RASSC screenshot attached

Thank you in advance.

entry.title: "Bulk" input a list of various materials and prices for automated PO creation
entry.content:
Hi all,

do you know is it possible to somehow "bulk" input a list of various materials and prices, associated with a single supplier for a specific period (for a project)? this is like creating a kind of price list from a supplier for a list of various materials from that supplier for a project? Would this be a source list? So far I've only worked with Info Records, and in videos I've only seen that they created source lists for individual materials... this Ideally in one step/transaction, and even better, by uploading the list?

Once this is done and the requirements are allocated in a WBS and the resulting PRs created, an automated process is expected to run, for example, every night, and automatically create a purchase order (PO) for that supplier with the materials required for that project (and the same for each subsequent project, not mixing requirements of different projects in one PO)?

Depending on the business unit, purchases are always made to the parent company in one country or another (business unit "A" always buys from one parent company, and business unit "B" always buys from another parent company).

What would then the step-by-step process of the automated periodic purchase be?

Thanks in advance for your guidance!

Wish you a great day!

entry.title: Re: SAP PUBLIC CLOUD EVENT - Billing Document Created
entry.content:
Dear @gianmaria_bonvini,

Yes the Billing Document business object in Public Cloud provides business events as described on the SAP Help Portal Billing Document Events page

Link below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/03c04db2a7434731b7fe21dca77440da/28ff5a6e242249e0b82645ca26d46043.html

Best first option (no event, no API):

If your goal is simply, for example when the user creates a customer invoice, the header text should be filled automatically the cleanest approach in Public Cloud is Text Determination for Billing Header. This happens during document creation, so you avoid update after posting limitations.

In CBC look for the ID: 101292 - Set Up Text Determination for Billing Header

 

More details below:

This is the approach I‚Äôd recommend first because it stays fully standard and robust

Second option, if you still want events + API callback

Usually Yes, you need an additional license on BTP side to consume Public Cloud business events, you typically need an SAP BTP messaging service such as SAP Event Mesh or equivalent entitlement in your contract

Step by step (high-level):

  1. Create a Communication Arrangement for SAP_COM_0092
  2. Search for SAP_COM_0120 in Communication Arrangements
    • If available you can expose API_BILLING_DOCUMENT_SRV for BTP callback.
    • If no the API part is likely blocked often because the scope (1Z6) item isn‚Äôt active/entitled

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3462588

Example proces flow:

  1. User posts/creates the invoice in Public Cloud
  2. Public Cloud emits Billing Document Created event ->Event Mesh (via SAP_COM_0092)
  3. BTP consumes the event
  4. BTP calls API_BILLING_DOCUMENT_SRV via SAP_COM_0120 to create/update header text

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/03c04db2a7434731b7fe21dca77440da/78da10ca6df542acb5926ac921af99e9.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/03c04db2a7434731b7fe21dca77440da/65680dabb62546029175655482f85edc.html

https://api.sap.com/api/API_BILLING_DOCUMENT_SRV/resource/post_Cancel

Summary:

  • If the text is deterministic based on customer, sales org, payer, Incoterms, etc. use Set Up Text Determination for Billing Header in CBC is the standard way
  • Use events + API callback only if the text depends on logic/data that cannot be determined inside CBC/Public Cloud at creation time and accept that it becomes a BTP extension + API authorization topic

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: ABAP Platform in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA 2025 were released to the SAP customer base on October 8, 2025.

ABAP Platform 2025 is the technology platform underlying the release 2025 of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA and is shipped as part of these products, supporting only SAP HANA database with full exploitation of its advanced capabilities. In addition,  ABAP Platform 2025 is part of SAP S/4HANA Foundation 2025 for SAP HANA-only Add-Ons.

ABAP Platform 2025 is not shipped as a standalone product. ABAP Platform 2025 consists of the AS ABAP,  the ABAP development tools for Eclipse, and several additional technology components which are required to run SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA.

Previous versions of SAP S/4HANA Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA such as 1610, 1709, 1809, 1909, 2020, 2021, 2022 and 2023 can be upgraded directly to the 2025 release, which is based on ABAP Platform 2025 (corresponding to SAP_BASIS 816).

Product Highlights

Presentation

This presentation provides the SAP official external slide deck, just click on it to view:

Overview

ABAP Platform 2025 delivers innovations for the ABAP stack in different areas.

Clean core development

In August 2025, SAP enhanced its extensibility guidelines by introducing the new Clean core extensibility white paper. The sustainable and upgrade-safe ABAP extensibility model in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA fully relies on SAP clean core guiding principles, aiming to decouple custom extensions from SAP standard whenever possible. The refined SAP guidance for extensibility replaces binary clean core decisions with a more nuanced evaluation of classic ABAP extensions based on the clean core level concept. Evolving from the previous 3-tier model, the new extensibility model categorizes extensions into four levels (A, B, C, and D) and provides rules for ABAP classic extensions to meet the clean core level qualifications. Following this new clean core extensibility guidance the ABAP extensibility guide was updated with technical guidelines to support the clean core level concept. The ABAP extensibility model was changed from 3-tier model to ABAP Cloud development (level A) and classic ABAP development (levels B, C and D).

The overall clean core guidance remained unchanged: always striving for the highest possible level of extensibility. ABAP Cloud is the SAP‚Äôs recommended development model for all new custom extensions in SAP S/4HANA private cloud and on-premise systems, whereby the classic ABAP extensibility can still be used to reach clean core, with a focus on upgrade-stability and code quality. This enables SAP customers and partners to transition to a clean core incrementally and at their own speed. SAP provides guidance for ABAP clean core development by offering a recommended list of APIs (so-called ‚Äúclassic APIs‚Äù) to be used in classic ABAP development. For governance of ABAP clean core development, the ABAP test cockpit (ATC) now supports the clean core level concept with new ATC checks (see the blog post ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of clean core ABAP development). For governance of ABAP development for clean core in SAP S/4HANA private cloud or on-premise systems the remote ATC in SAP BTP ABAP environment is the SAP recommended approach. 

SAP Joule for Developers,  ABAP AI capabilities

SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities are now key components and an integral part of AI-assisted ABAP Cloud development, also facilitating custom code transformation from ECC to SAP S/4HANA. The capabilities supporting developer tasks include Joule copilot in ABAP development tools for Eclipse, predictive code completion, code explanation and unit test generation for ABAP and ABAP CDS, app and service generation (including RAP BO generation), predictive business logic for RAP BOs, and OData consumption. The provided ABAP AI SDK, powered by Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM), can be utilized for the implementation of AI capabilities in custom applications.

The custom code migration capabilities include docs chat for questions around custom code migration and S/4HANA simplifications, explanation of business purpose and processing logic of legacy code (ABAP reports), explanation of S/4HANA-related ATC findings in custom code, along with resolution recommendations based on S/4HANA simplification items and cookbooks (see the blog post SAP Joule for Developers Expands to Private Cloud: Accelerating ABAP Innovation and Transformation).

ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP)

Another major investment area in the 2025 release is the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model, which powers modern development in both ABAP Cloud and classic ABAP, enabling the creation of delightful transactional SAP Fiori apps as well as local and web APIs. This release delivers new features to accelerate and enhance the development with RAP, including new generators to boost efficiency, support of CDS table entities as persistence layer, various capabilities for SAP Fiori elements-based UIs, such as collaborative draft, cross-BO scenarios, tree views, and event-driven side effects, as well as end-to-end extensibility options.

New ABAP Cloud generators for creating OData UI services with RAP BOs (with one or more entities) from scratch, with or without AI assistance, or for generating custom UI service based on RAP BO interface are provided. ABAP CDS table entities can be used as active persistence layer for managed RAP BOs without draft, replacing classic dictionary database tables.

Enhancements for building of SAP Fiori elements-based apps with RAP include the collaborative draft handling, which allows multiple users to work simultaneously and collaboratively on the same draft instance of an entity without blocking one another. You can now also build SAP Fiori UIs that use multiple RAP BOs interacting with each other. These cross-BO scenarios rely on cross-BO transactional enablement, where the entities of the participating RAP BOs are linked through so-called cross-BO associations. Read-only and editable tree view supports displaying and manipulating hierarchical data in SAP Fiori UIs, with options for drag and drop, cut and paste, reordering, and cascading delete. Event-driven RAP side effects enable asynchronous updates in SAP Fiori UIs. When such a specific RAP business event is raised, the associated side effect is triggered, and the defined targets are reloaded in the UI.

The privileged context can now be propagated in subsequent Entity Manipulation Language (EML) requests in reading and modifying operation. Further enhancement for the behavior definitions and the behavior pools are provided with this release.

ABAP development tools for Eclipse (ADT)

Various enhancements are provided in ABAP development tools for Eclipse for ABAP development, RAP and ABAP CDS related development aspects, testing and troubleshooting, as well as overall IDE and productivity improvements.

Refactoring support for ABAP classes and interfaces was improved by activation of renaming changes by default, validation of new names and displaying long texts of exceptions. The new where-used dialog enables prefiltering of search results to focus on usages relevant for the concrete use case. There is a new property abaplv to filter object searches with the ABAP language version. There are new editors like for example for working with software component relations, Adobe Forms or maintaining intelligent scenarios and intelligent scenarios models which are required to run a solution based on generative AI. It is possible to create and edit CDS table entities and create for them behavior definitions.

In the area of ABAP unit tests, method calls in test classes can now be highlighted in different colors to distinguish their method contexts. Quick actions allow tests to be launched or templates for test classes to be inserted with a single mouse click. The failed assertions and status of test methods can be displayed directly in the source code editor. The unit tests can be rerun with coverage and coverage results can be cleared in the ABAP Coverage view. Additionally, there is a new AMDP Test Double Framework, and the CDS Test Double Framework now supports CDS hierarchy views.

In the ABAP debugger, it is now possible to display the memory consumption of a debugged ABAP program in the new ABAP Memory (Debugger) view. The ABAP Memory Snapshot view lists all memory snapshots, which can be opened in the editor to show memory objects ranked by size. These views make it easier to analyze the memory usage of an ABAP application. Internal tables can now be easily compared using the table comparison tool within the ABAP debugger. Beyond this, the ABAP debugger can now consider variables with hidden values (for sensitive data), display variables of type JSON, and show component groups for nested structures in the Variables view. Collaborative error analysis is supported by export/import of ABAP Cross Trace results to/from JSON file or export of short dumps as ZIP file in the ABAP Runtime Error Viewer.

Beyond this there are also enhancements in transport management for adding an object to a transport or searching and grouping transport requests.

ABAP Language

The modern, declarative, and expression-oriented ABAP language allows writing simple and concise ABAP code through features such as inline declarations and constructor expressions. Advanced operations for internal tables include grouping, filtering, and the CORRESPONDING( ) operator. The cloud-optimized version ‚ÄúABAP for Cloud Development‚Äù is used for ABAP Cloud development.

There are further enhancements for internal tables, including support for arbitrary logical expressions and equality conditions, as well as harmonization of table expressions and READ TABLE statement. New ABAP system classes for probability distributions are provided, enabling the generation of random number and the calculation of quantile, probabilities, and other aspects. These classes support various discrete and continuous distributions. This release also delivers enhancements for expressions and functions, as well as for transformations, such as the new domain XSDGEO for serializing and deserializing spatial data between the Extended Well-Known Binary (EWKB) representation and the GeoJSON format.

SAP HANA-centric optimizations & Data Integration scenarios

Modern ABAP development on SAP HANA has been enhanced with several advanced, database-centric features also enriching data integration scenarios. Recent innovations in data integration focus on data exposure, including ABAP-managed database procedures for advanced read scenarios.  With CDS updatable view entities it is now possible to wrap existing DDIC database tables (or CDS table entities) and expose a native CDS signature, which can be used with ABAP SQL in combination with DCL-based access control. 

On the consumption side, new write scenarios, the use of static CDS external entities, and the possibility to create ABAP CDS models based on imported CDS models make it easier than ever to integrate external data seamlessly into an ABAP CDS view stack.

Additional enhancements, such as CDS table entities to define and manage SAP HANA database tables as native CDS repository objects, a CDS generation wizard to simplify and automate the creation of hierarchically structured data in ABAP CDS, and AI-powered CDS Explain to get semantical context information about CDS entities further brighten the ABAP development landscape.

Embedded analytics

For embedded analytics scenarios it is now possible to expedite development workflow using ABAP Cloud generator wizards for creation of multidimensional analysis apps, Review Booklet apps, or native CDS hierarchy definitions. With the introduction of reusable measures and filters, the key figures, measures, filters and many more features can now be defined centrally, based on user needs to better manage and align analytical reporting. They can also be utilized in CDS view entities to ensure homogenous definition of complex calculations and unification of coherences of the running business.

Event Enablement & Business Events

The event-driven architecture of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA is strengthened, and the interoperability across enterprise solutions is improved through seamless integration with SAP Event Mesh Advanced Plan and support of SAP Cloud Application Event Hub to consume events published by SAP Order Management Foundation on SAP BTP.

The event-driven processing and monitoring was enhanced with new outbound event filtering, enabling selective publishing based on configurable criteria, and dynamic topics in SAP Event Mesh Advanced Plan for more efficient routing. Operational transparency was improved through comprehensive event logging, including local capture and logging of successfully processed events. Events of the same type and object within a session can now be grouped as activities, improving traceability and reducing monitoring noise. Together, these features provide a scalable and well-governed foundation for event-driven architecture.

Process integration & Connectivity

Key highlights of process integration include a robust OData service consumption model with Swagger UI preview and advanced OData V4 capabilities, such as bulk processing and asynchronous communication integrated with AIF. The API governance and communication management was enhanced by introducing Communication Targets within Communication Arrangements, enabling more granular control over connectivity endpoints. API lifecycle management is improved through API-to-package assignment and the ability to create API packages for better organization across API types. Additionally, OData-based access to Communication Management data increases automation, transparency, and integration with external tools.

Additional connectivity improvements include outbound communication enablement via HTTP and RFC, support for setting the AIR key as a custom HTTP header in SOAP requests for more secure message handling, direct push-based data exchange between ABAP systems via RFC, and SSE support in the ABAP HTTP client and server for efficient real-time event delivery in distributed scenarios.

Key user extensibility

Further improvements are provided for key user extensibility. It is now possible to generate a Fiori elements application for a custom business object with just one click and maintain behavior extensions for SAP-provided RAP business objects using key user extensibility. Moreover, using developer extensibility it is now possible to implement feature control for custom fields that were created via the Custom Fields app. The new extension field wizard provides a better development efficiency by boosting the creation of custom fields via developer extensibility.

Security

Key updates include support for OAuth Authorization Code with PKCE (RFC 7636) and JWT-based client authentication (RFC 7523), as well as SAP-managed client certificates for secure integration in S/4HANA Private Cloud (2025 FPS01). TLS 1.3 is now supported across HTTP, WebSocket RFC, and SMTP, with OAuth Client Credential Grant enabled for SMTP outbound scenarios such as Exchange Online.

Additional enhancements include new OpenID Connect features, improved troubleshooting guidance (SAP Note 3111813), and a new OAuth Client Configuration UI (SOAUTH_CLIENT) with built-in testing and token metadata display.
