entry.title: Timestamp Conversion for Different User Time Zones in ABAP
entry.content:
Hello Everyone!

Recently, I worked on a timestamp conversion issue related to user-specific time zones in SAP. The data stored in the SAP level was correct, but when displayed through an ABAP report, the timestamp appeared incorrect for some users.

After analyzing the issue, I found that the root cause was the conversion routine defined in the domain. This routine automatically converts timestamps based on the user's logon time zone, which caused mismatches during display.

In this blog, I will show how to resolve this issue by converting all timestamps to UTC before displaying them, ensuring consistent results for every user‚Äîregardless of their time zone or domain settings.

Problem Summary

  • The timestamp stored in the database table (ZDEL_INFO) was correct.

  • But when displaying the data in a report, the timestamp appeared incorrect for some users.

  • This happened because the domain of the timestamp field had a conversion routine (e.g., TZNTSTMPS).

  • As a result, SAP automatically converted timestamps based on each user's time zone.

Example:

Domain with Conversion Routine:

Table:

Report:

Solution Approach

  1. Read timestamp values from the database.

  2. Convert local timestamp ‚Üí UTC timestamp using:

cl_kf_helper=>timestamp_local_zone_2_utc

3.Populate the final internal table with the corrected timestamp.

4.Display the data using CL_SALV_TABLE.

By converting timestamps to UTC, the displayed values remain consistent for all users.

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ZTIMESTAMPS_USERS
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Purpose:
*&   This report reads delivery data from table ZDEL_INFO,
*&   converts local timestamps into UTC based on the user‚Äôs time zone,
*&   and displays the results using CL_SALV_TABLE.
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT ztimestamps_users.

TABLES: zdel_info.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_del,
       deliveryno TYPE zdel_info-deliveryno,
       material   TYPE zdel_info-material,
       deldate    TYPE zdel_info-deldate,
END OF ty_del.

DATA: lt_final TYPE TABLE OF ty_del,
      ls_final TYPE ty_del.


*START-OF-SELECTION.

START-OF-SELECTION.

SELECT * FROM zdel_info
        INTO TABLE (lt_del).

LOOP AT lt_del INTO DATA(ls_del).

ls_final-deliveryno = ls_del-deliveryno.
ls_final-material   = ls_del-material.
IF ls_del-deldate IS  NOT INITIAL.

CALL METHOD cl_kf_helper=>timestamp_local_zone_2_utc
          EXPORTING
            i_timestamp_local = ls_del-deldate          " Timestamp in user's local time
            i_time_zone       = sy-zonlo                " Current user's time zone
          RECEIVING
            r_timestamp_utc   = DATA(lv_tmstamputc).    " Converted UTC timestamp

ls_final-deldate = lv_tmstamputc.
        CLEAR lv_tmstamputc.

ENDIF.
APPEND ls_final TO lt_final.
ENDLOOP.

DATA: o_alv TYPE REF TO cl_salv_table.

  cl_salv_table=>factory(
      IMPORTING
        r_salv_table = o_alv
      CHANGING
        t_table      = lt_final ).

* Display the ALV
o_alv->display( ).

Output:

Explanation of Key Logic

1. timestamp_local_zone_2_utc

This method converts a timestamp from the user‚Äôs local time zone (based on SY-ZONLO) to UTC.

2. Why Convert to UTC?

UTC is a universal reference.
Once converted to UTC, the timestamp remains consistent, regardless of:

  • User logon time zone

  • System time zone

  • Conversion routines in the domain

3. Output Using SALV

CL_SALV_TABLE is used for a simple and clean ALV output without advanced configuration.

Conclusion

Handling timestamps in SAP can be challenging, especially when conversion routines and user time zones come into play.
By converting timestamps to UTC before displaying them, we avoid incorrect values and ensure reliable reporting across all users.
It will have been Very Helpful for Real Time users in Project works
this has a process of just like small solution  thank you...


ABAP Development 
ABAP Connectivity 
ABAP Extensibility

entry.title: Hierarchical ALV Using Factory Method in SAP ABAP
entry.content:
In this blog post, we‚Äôll explore how to implement a Hierarchical ALV using the Factory Method of the CL_SALV_HIERSEQ_TABLE class.

Introduction

In many SAP ERP scenarios, business users frequently work with data that follows a natural master‚Äìdetail relationship, such as customers and their contacts, vendors and their company-code assignments, or materials and their storage locations. Presenting such related datasets in a clean and intuitive format is critical for efficient decision-making.

While traditional ALV is highly effective for displaying single-level tables, it becomes less practical when dealing with multi-level or dependent datasets. For these situations, SAP provides Hierarchical ALV through the class CL_SALV_HIERSEQ_TABLE, allowing developers to present complex data relationships in an expandable, easy-to-navigate layout within SAP GUI.

This blog demonstrates how to create a hierarchical ALV using a vendor master table and its corresponding item details. The objective is to show how straightforward it is to bind two related datasets, define the hierarchy mapping, and display the result using SAP‚Äôs SALV framework‚Äîall with clean, maintainable ABAP code.

Scenario Overview

We will work with two custom tables:

  • ZVA_VENDOR_TA ‚Äì Stores vendor master information (header level).

  • ZVA_VENDOR_ITEM ‚Äì Stores vendor-specific or company-code-specific details (item level).

The goal is to display these tables in a hierarchical ALV, where each vendor (header) can be expanded to reveal its associated item entries (detail).

CODE:

REPORT ZVA_FACTORY_HIERACY_ALV.

" Declaration of internal tables and work areas for hierarchical ALV binding
DATA: LT_HIERSEQ TYPE SALV_T_HIERSEQ_BINDING,
      LS_HIERSEQ TYPE SALV_S_HIERSEQ_BINDING.

" Select vendor master data from custom table ZVA_VENDOR_TA
SELECT VENDERNO, NAME, CITY, POSTALCODE, EMAIL, ACCOUNTGROUP, PROCESSORGROUP, POSTINGBLOCK
  FROM ZVA_VENDOR_TA INTO TABLE (LT_VENDOR).

" Check if data is available in the LT_VENDOR table
IF sy-subrc = 0.

  " If vendor data exists, select corresponding vendor item details from ZVA_VENDOR_ITEM
  SELECT VENDERNO, COMPANYCODE, PERSONNELNUMBER, AUTHORGROUP, NTGEW, GEWEI, EKORG, STATUS
    FROM ZVA_VENDOR_ITEM INTO  TABLE (LT_VENDOR_ITEM).

ENDIF.

" Define the hierarchy relationship between the master and detail tables
LS_HIERSEQ-MASTER = 'VENDERNO'.  " Master key field (header level)
LS_HIERSEQ-SLAVE  = 'VENDERNO'.  " Corresponding key field in detail (item level)
APPEND LS_HIERSEQ TO LT_HIERSEQ. " Add the mapping to the hierarchy sequence table

" Create and display the hierarchical ALV using CL_SALV_HIERSEQ_TABLE
CALL METHOD CL_SALV_HIERSEQ_TABLE=>FACTORY
  EXPORTING
    T_BINDING_LEVEL1_LEVEL2 = LT_HIERSEQ       " Define the binding between header and item tables
  IMPORTING
    R_HIERSEQ               = DATA(LO_SALV_HIERSEQ) " Get reference to the hierarchical ALV object
  CHANGING
    T_TABLE_LEVEL1          = LT_VENDOR         " Pass header (vendor) data
    T_TABLE_LEVEL2          = LT_VENDOR_ITEM.   " Pass item (vendor details) data

" Display the hierarchical ALV
LO_SALV_HIERSEQ->DISPLAY( ).

Output :

Conclusion

Hierarchical ALV is a powerful tool for presenting master‚Äìdetail datasets in an organized and interactive format. The class CL_SALV_HIERSEQ_TABLE significantly simplifies the development process by handling the hierarchy logic internally, allowing developers to focus on data retrieval and business requirements rather than UI complexity.

By implementing this approach, organizations can deliver reports that are not only visually clear but also easier for end users to navigate‚Äîespecially when dealing with multi-level relational data. This technique remains highly relevant for SAP GUI-based reporting and continues to be an important part of the ABAP developer‚Äôs toolkit.

If needed, this solution can be extended to support additional hierarchy levels, custom toolbar functions, or integration with business logic, making it flexible enough for advanced reporting scenarios.

ABAP Development

entry.title: Re: Question on MDK Extension Project & Version Control B...
entry.content: Typically you would put your ZSAPAssetManager also under version control.   If you have additional changes to make you would make them in the same ZSAPAssetManager project.  When deploying the .cim files in the base SAPAssetManager project control what is used.  If you have multiple CIM project the .cim files are processed in alphabetical order.  So if two extension projects indicate the same file is modified, the last .cim file processed wins.

entry.title: Re: Export and Import statements using memory id Help
entry.content:
Hi,
You state that in debug the code in EXIT_SAPL0VRF_001 is hit for both shipping points.
In that case the memmory value should be 'Y' in both cases.
I deduct from your explanation that also the code in MV50AFZ1 is hit and for one of the shipping points it is no longer 'Y'.

The reasons I can think of why it is not working are:

  1. The value only gets set for the one shipping point and not for the second one.
    But you stated that this was checked in debug and should be fine (just wanted to mention it again to double check)
  2. The value gets cleared in the flow in between the two points.
    - This could be either that the memory ID is already used for something else somewhere in between, this is hard to find because it could really be anywhere.
    - The flow is just slightly different due to customizing, causing the non-working shipping point to use two sessions whereby the memory parameter is not available in a new session.

So, what can you do:

  1. Try to use a different memory parameter name, making it so specifically named that it is guaranteed to not be used anywhere
  2. Use singleton class to buffer the value instead of working with export/import, this would also have the benefit that where used can be leveraged to find where it is set/read at any point in the future. But mostly it will give certainty that it is not used anywhere yet.
    You can also use a watchpoint (or regular breakpoint) on the attribute of the singleton class to know exactly when it gets changed in the flow.
  3. Do a trace of both cases and check what is different. 
    This might take a lot of time.

I hope it can at least be of some use or bring new ideas for troubleshooting.

entry.title: Primary and Secondary keys concept in Debugging
entry.content:
Introduction

In this blog we will be discussing on Primary and Secondary keys concept in Debugging,

Primary keys uniquely identify each record, making it easier to trace and isolate errors with precision. Secondary keys provide alternative access paths and relational context, helping uncover integrity issues, performance bottlenecks or constraint violations during analysis. Together, they form the backbone of accurate and efficient debugging .

1.How to check Primary and Secondary keys in Debugging.

Let us consider the Standard table type which is having 3 primary Non-unique keys and 1 Non-unique secondary key as shown below

TYPES: 
   tt_t100 TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF t100 
   WITH KEY sprsl arbgb msgnr                " Primary Key 
   WITH NON-UNIQUE SORTED KEY lang_text      " Secondary Key 
     COMPONENTS sprsl text. 
 
DATA: t_t100 TYPE tt_t100. 
 
 
select * FROM t100 INTO TABLE @t_t100 UP TO 50 ROWS.

In debugging, double click on the Internal table t_t100 to observe the Primary and Secondary keys in Key dropdown.


2.How many Primary and Secondary keys we have and how we are differentiating them in Debugging.

Click on key /indexes Icon which is on left side of Attributes to see the number of keys, uniqueness and type of Internal table.

We can observe Primary key values in blue and Secondary keys value in Black

 

 

Conclusion

In debugging prospective, primary keys help pinpoint the exact record causing the issue, ensuring precision. Secondary keys provide relational context and highlight integrity or indexing problems, helps in explaining why the error occurred. Together, they deliver both accuracy and insight.

entry.title: Master Data Consistency Analyzer - MDCA
entry.content:
Introduction

MDCA tool (Master Data consistency Analyzer) was previously called as MICE (Master Data Inconsistency Evaluator).
It can be used to identify the data inconsistencies across applications.CVI (Customer vendor integration), BP (Business partner), Address etc that are configured to the MDCA framework. All the inconsistencies in an application can be identified in one go, or inconsistencies can be identified for specific objects based on the selection criteria. MDCA tool can be considered as a one stop solution to identify all data inconsistencies for an application which will eventually save a lot of time and effort and ensure seamless process flow.

Target audience

Functional expert

Release Status

This transaction MICE is in restricted release mode for exclusive use by SAP Support.

Results may not be accurate and may not reflect current state of data.

Do not execute this transaction without written guidance from SAP.       

Prerequisites

Before Implementing the notes in the sequence listed below, please read the SAP Note 3353957.

Implement the SAP Notes listed below in strict sequence. In case any Note implementation status is incorrect or incomplete, stop and report back the issue to SAP Support. Do not proceed further with the implementation without resolving implementation issues from previous Notes.

MDCA Framework Notes :

1. Note 2956974 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 1

    This Note contains the package 'S_BUPA_TOOLS' in which the MDCA framework objects are developed.

    There will be activation issues for other objects in this Note, as the DDIC objects will be created from the next Notes below.

    Just make sure the package 'S_BUPA_TOOLS' is created sucessfully during the implementation of this Note.

2. Note 3532897 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 2

3. Note 3500434 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 3

    Once the above 3 notes are implemented, implement the first note again as mentiond below.

4. Note 2956974 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 1

5. Note 3232130 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 4

6. Note 3362331 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 5

7. Note 3384523 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 6

8. Note 3472055 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - Framework Note 7

Post implementing above Notes, go to SE80 transaction,check and activate if there is any inactive objects in package 'S_BUPA_TOOLS'.

Business Partner ( BUPA ) Application Notes for MDCA Framework:

9. Note 3396047 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - BP Application Note 1

10. Note 3396036 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - BP Application Note 2

11. Note 3485146 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - BP Application Note 3

12. Note 3514136 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - BP Application Note 4

CVI Application Notes for MICE Framework :

13.Note 3512942 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - CVI Application Note 1

14. Note 3025283 :- MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) - CVI Application Note 2

Currently, there is no change Logs functionality enabled.

This will be automatically updated via the relevant SPs across relevant Releases.

Usage

MDCA tool can be launched using the transaction code MICE.

Active applications configured in MDCA framework will appear in the list and needs to be selected, which will enable the user to enter selection screen parameters for execution.

- Background Execution
The button ‚ÄòExecute in Background‚Äô will help to run the tool in background which is advised when running for large number of inconsistencies.  The 'Find' option will find all the inconsistencies. All the inconsistency details along with their statuses will be stored in the spool and will be available in ‚ÄòRun History‚Äô section post completion of the background job for display.

- Foreground execution
The foreground execution of MDCA tool will display an ALV with all the inconsistencies based on the selection parameters.

‚ÄòRun history‚Äô section in the selection screen will store the details for each execution (Background and foreground) and can be used for analysis at a later point of time if required. Upon selecting an entry from run history, the details will be displayed in the ALV.

Basic Tech info

Transaction code MICEMVS can be used to display the standard applications and other configurations delivered by SAP. Master data, table field, parameters and message nodes will be configured for each application which will help in execution of the MDCA tool. The application registered with active status will appear on the MDCA tool. 

Transaction MICEMV can be used to register custom applications. Master data, table field, parameters and message nodes must be configured as per the design. The custom class should refer to interface MICE_IF_WRAPPER for successful registration.
For more detais, please check 3353957 - MDCA ( Master Data Consistency Analyzer ) :- Functional Details

Successful configuration will generate the include programs MICE_GENERATE1 and MICE_GENERATE2 which will be used for dynamic generation of selection screen fields in MDCA tool.

Message node must be maintained with message class and message number details along with parameters to be displayed in the MDCA tool output. The criticality field is used to prioritize the inconsistencies while listing in the output.

MICE transaction is used to launch the MDCA tool. The selection screen will be displayed based on the configurations in MICEMV and MICEMVS.

The screen fields will be displayed based on the application selected. The tool can be executed, either by providing basic field values or by providing additional filters based on 'Specific' parameter option. Please refer attachments 'Initial screen' and 'Specific Parameters'.

After execution, all the inconsistencies will be displayed based on the selection criteria provided.Inconsistencies can be analysed further by checking the message text and additional parameters. Please refer attachment 'MICE -Output Screen'.

How to get SAP support for this tool
